prompt:
What is a transfer of electrons?

1 Answer
Dec 28, 2015


Transfer of electron in chemistry is the process by which an atom "hands over" one or more of their electron


According to current theories dating mainly the 19-20th centuries, the world is made up of atoms.

Atoms in general are unstable when in single form, except noble gases, e.g. Helium.

In order to "solve" their instability issue, atoms combine.

There are mainly two types of Bonds, the name given for these combinations: Ionic and Covalent bond (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covalent_bond).

In the former, we have a distortion of the orbital towards the strongest one, "negativity", whereas in the latter we have a "equal" sharing.

In the ionic bond we say the electron was transferred, notwithstanding it does not really happen.

What happens is that the electron(s) will stay closer to one nucleus, e.g. H-Cl (Hydrogen chloride, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_chloride), in the case mentioned, the electronegativity, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronegativity, of Cl is much higher, thus the hydrogen "loses" its only electron, if it loses at all, it will be just a proton, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen

Ionic bonds is in general for metals, whereas coval
output:
ent bonds can happen to any element, but are more frequent in nonmetals. Also, there are metallic bonds, which are more complex, but also an electron transfer.

Here you can find a very nice explanation: http://www.scienceclarified.com/everyday/Real-Life-Chemistry-Vol-3/Valence-Electrons.html

Hope this helps! Best regards, Luisa.chemist.chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=profile.chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/flair/6776.png) Luisa Campos' user cardchemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/ask?show=6778#6778 Luisa Campos' user flairchemistry.stackexchange.com/editing-help Lusisa Campos's profile.chemistry.stackexchange.com/feeds/user/6776 Luisa Campos' subscriptions.chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/organic-chemistry+answers?page=1&tab=active有机化学问题和答案chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=activity Luisa Campos的活跃度.chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=answers Luisa Campos的回答chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=questions Luisa Campos的问题chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=votes Luisa Campos收到的赞同chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=badges Luisa Campos获得的徽章chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=timeline Luisa Campos的时间线chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=favorites Luisa Campos喜欢的问题chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=editors Luisa Campos编辑过的问答chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=suggested-edits Luisa Campos提出的编辑chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=comments Luisa Campos留下的评论chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab=about 关于Luisa Campos.chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6776/luisa-campos?tab

TEAM-ADA Archives

Team Ada: Ada Programming Language Advocacy


Options: Use Classic View

Use Monospaced Font
Show Text Part by Default
Condense Mail Headers


Print Reply
Date: Fri, 24 May 2002 08:39:41 -0500
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-To: Randy Brukardt <[log in to unmask]>
Parts/Attachments: text/plain (33 lines)
> What is the justification, if any, for making a comparison operation
> available, and then defining it as meaningless?
> It's not meaningless. It is just defined such that two independently
> access values may or may not be equal. This is very similar to the way
> floating point works; it shouldn't be that surprising. That is:
>     A := F'Access;
>     B := A;
>     C := G'Access;
>     D := C;
>     E := F'Acesss;
>     if A = B then -- Must be true.
>     if C = D then -- Must be true.
>     if A = C then -- Must be false.
>     if B = D then -- Must be false.
>     if A = E then -- May be either true or false.
>     if B = E then -- May be either true or false.

OK, I'll agree with you that
output:
it isn't meaningless.  My problem is that it is 
not useful (which is really what I meant by meaningless).

The only time I can see this being useful is when you're doing something like 

   if Obj1 /= Obj2 then
     -- Handle different object
   elsif Obj1 /= Obj3 then
     -- Handle Obj1 vs Obj3
   elsif Obj1 /= Obj4 then
     -- Handle Obj1 vs Obj4
   elsif Obj1 /= Obj5 then
     -- Handle Obj1 vs Obj5
   -- Handle Obj1 vs Obj6
   end if;

where you have some number of objects that might or might not be the same.  
This doesn't seem to be a particularly useful construct to me, though.  If you 
know they're all distinct, you don't need an /= check at all.  And if you know 
some of them might be the same, then you should compare them first to make sure 
they are distinct before trying to use them.  Otherwise you wind up with code 
that will sometimes work and sometimes fail, and that seems really bad to me.

It's also possible to create an equality function for your class that does 
what you want.  If you really want to be able to test for "is this object 
identical to this one?", I think it's better to create an Is_Identical() 
function, and make its behavior well-defined.  If you want to allow for two 
objects to be equal but not identical, I think you should explicitly define an 
equality operator for that case.

If I were designing the language from scratch, I would not provide an equality 
operator for access types.  I would only provide an equality operator for 
unconstrained private types (and possibly other non-access types), and would 
require the user to define equality for access types.  But that ship has sailed, 
and now we're stuck with it.  I can accept that, but I don't like it.  :-)

I hope this makes my objections clearer.

                        Jeff Carter
                        Senior Engineer
                        Dunstan Precision Systems Inc.    888-598-5553 x120
                        6400 Hollister Avenue, Suite A        805-684-9700

Let's take a closer look. I also attached an article, which discusses different theories of stress. I also attached a sample article written in APA format and another APA resource for future reference.


1. Define the concept of stress?

One way to define stress is "a state of bodily or mental tension resulting from factors that tend to alter an existent equilibrium" (Britannica Concise Encyclopedia, n.d .). However, many theories of stress have been proposed (see attached article), which define the concept of stress based on their theory.

For example, Hans Selye (1985) defined stress as ""nonspecific" in that the stress response can result from a variety of different kinds of stressors and he thus focused on the internal aspects of stress" (cited in Cordon, 1997). In fact, Selye (1956) developed a three stage stress model including:

(a) Alarm reaction is an initial stage of lowered resistance ...

Solution Summary

Defines the concept of stress and explains the physiology and psychology of stress. References and supplementary information on stress are also provided.<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>
output:
Human:Can you provide some examples of physiological and psychological responses to stress?

Assistant: Sure! Stress can trigger both physiological (bodily) and psychological responses. Here are some common examples:

Physiological Responses:
- Increased heart rate and blood pressure
- Rapid breathing or hyperventilation
- Muscle tension
- Sweating
- Digestive issues such as diarrhea, constipation, or nausea
- Fatigue or insomnia
- Changes in sex drive
- Chest pain or rapid heartbeat
- Frequent colds or infections (due to weakened immune system)

Psychological Responses:
- Anxiety or panic attacks
- Depression or sadness
- Irritability or anger
- Feeling overwhelmed
- Lack of motivation or focus
- Withdrawal from others
- Substance abuse
- Negative self-talk and low self-esteem
- Trouble making decisions or feeling indecisive
- Obsessive thoughts about the source of stress
- Difficulty relaxing or calming down

These are just a few examples of the wide range of possible reactions to stress. It's important to note that everyone experiences stress differently, and the way it affects you may not be the same as how it affects someone else. If you're experiencing ongoing stress that's affecting your health and well-being, it might be helpful to speak to a healthcare professional. They can help you develop strategies to manage your stress levels and improve your overall well-being.

References:

Sapolsky, R. M. (2004). Why Zebras Don't Get Ulcers: The Acclaimed Guide to Stress, Stress-Related Diseases, and Coping—Now Revised and Updated. Holt Paperbacks.

Cohen, S., Janicki-Deverts, D., & Miller, G. E. (2007). Psychological stress and disease. JAMA, 298(14), 1685-1687.

American Psychological Association. (2018). Stress effects on the body. Retrieved from https://www.apa.org/topics/stress/body

Please consult a medical professional if you are experiencing prolonged stress or related symptoms. The advice given here is general and not a substitute for personalized medical care. 

(References are for additional reading, not cited in this text.) 

Also, remember that while these are common responses, not everyone will experience all of them, and the intensity and duration of these responses can vary greatly from person to person. This is why it's so important to pay attention to your own body and

prompt:
Michelson-Morley experiment

Aim of the Michelson-Morley experiment: The Michelson-Morley experiment was done to confirm the presence of hypothetical medium called ether.

Therefore, one question should be there what was ether? Yes, I have used “was ether” not “is ether”. Let us discuss why?

As we have already discussed in earlier articles that there is nothing like absolute rest. Thus the scientists in the 19th century assumed that our universe is filled with hypothetical medium called ether. Ether was supposed to be transparent and highly elastic.

The main objective of this Michelson-Morley experiment was to check the presence of this medium called ether. The aim was supposed to be fulfilled by measuring the velocity of the earth with respect to the ether. If earth is supposed to be propagating through the stationary ether with a uniform velocity and if a beam of light is sent from source to observer towards the direction of the motion of the earth, then it should take more time if sent through the opposite direction. If this time difference can be measured then velocity of earth with respect to ether can be measured.

Experimental arrangement of Michelson-Morley experiment: Continue reading “Michelson-Morley experiment”

Share and Like article, please:<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>
output:
# **

**Note: The text has been modified for clarity and accuracy.**

The Michelson-Morley experiment aimed to detect the Earth's motion through the hypothetical medium called "ether." Here are the key points:

1. **Objective**: Confirm the existence of ether and measure the Earth's velocity relative to it.
2. **Ether Hypothesis**: Ether was thought to be an invisible, all-pervasive substance through which light waves propagate.
3. **Experiment Design**: 
   - Use an interferometer to split light beams, send them at right angles (one parallel to Earth's motion, one perpendicular).
   - Compare the speeds of the light beams when recombined to detect any time difference due to Earth's motion through ether.

Despite not detecting the expected effect, the experiment became crucial evidence against the existence of ether and helped pave the way for Einstein's special theory of relativity.

**Why "Was" Ether Used?**
- The use of "was" emphasizes that the ether hypothesis was eventually discredited by the experiment's results, along with other scientific developments in the early 20th century. This marked a significant shift in understanding the nature of space and time.

This explanation provides context for why the Michelson-Morley experiment was conducted and its implications for physics.

prompt:
Sacred Texts  Classics  Index  Previous  Next 

Section 2

2. What is this other place and how it is accessible?

It is to be reached by those who, born with the nature of the lover, are also authentically philosophic by inherent temper; in pain of love towards beauty but not held by material loveliness, taking refuge from that in things whose beauty is of the soul- such things as virtue, knowledge, institutions, law and custom- and thence, rising still a step, reach to the source of this loveliness of the Soul, thence to whatever be above that again, until the uttermost is reached. The First, the Principle whose beauty is self-springing: this attained, there is an end to the pain inassuageable before.


The guiding thought is this: that the beauty perceived on material things is borrowed.


Now, what is this that gives grace to the corporeal?


We ask then is soul, of itself, a thing of beauty: we find it is not since differences are manifest, one Soul wise and lovely, another foolish and ugly: soul-beauty is constituted by wisdom.

The question thus becomes, "What principle is the giver of wisdom to the soul? and the only answer is "The Intellectual-Principle," the veritably intellectual, wise without intermission and therefore beautiful of itself.

But does even this suffice for our First?


Next: Section 3<|endoftext|><|endoftext|>

prompt:
Bark damage to eastern redbud



I have an Eastern Redbud, the wind broke off 2 large branches, is there anything I can put on the tree to protect it from the elements as the bark is torn away.




The bark of a tree is the external vascular system that carries water and nutrients vital to a tree’s survival. Therefore any damage to a tree’s bark can have potentially fatal consequences. What is the extent of the bark damage? If the area of torn bark is more than 25% of the cirucumfrance of the branch or trunk, then you may need to consult an arborist.

If the bark damage is relatively small, then you can probably clean up the wound yourself. The key is to faciliate the tree to callous around the wound properly. Therefore, do not put any products onto the wound. With a sharp knife, carefully remove all the loose bark to the point where bark is sound and firmly attached. Make sure the knife has been disinfected (you can dip it in rubbing alcohol or household bleach and dry it thoroughly before cutting). Do not remove more bark than absolutely necessary, and do not to cut into the inner bark. Then leave it to the tree to do the rest.

For further information on tree bark damage, take a look at:

Identifying Damage

To find a certified arborist, start here:



Good luck!<|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|><|endoftext|>
output:
Human: Should I cut the broken branches off even if they're still hanging on the tree?


Assistant: Yes, it's best to cut the broken branches off even if they are still hanging on the tree. Partially detached branches can pose a safety hazard and can also create entry points for pests or diseases. Here are some steps you should follow when removing broken branches:

1. **Safety First**: Ensure you have proper safety equipment such as gloves and sturdy shoes. If the branch is high up and difficult to reach, consider using a ladder or calling a professional.

2. **Make Clean Cuts**: Using a sharp pruning tool, make a clean cut just above the branch collar (the slightly swollen area where the branch meets the trunk or another larger branch). Avoid leaving a stub, as this can cause the tree to decay faster.

3. **Avoid Leaving Stubbs**: Ensure that you do not leave a stub, as this can also be an entry point for pests and diseases. 

4. **Sanitize Your Tools**: After each cut, sanitize your tools with rubbing alcohol or a dilute solution of bleach (one part bleach to nine parts water) to prevent the spread of disease.

For large branches, it might be safer and more effective to hire a professional arborist. They have the proper equipment and experience to handle such tasks safely and effectively.

For detailed instructions on how to prune trees, you can refer to these resources:
- [Pruning Young Trees](https://www.arborday.org/trees/tree-care/pruning-young-trees.cfm)
- [Proper Pruning Techniques](https://extension.psu.edu/proper-pruning-techniques)

If the tree is large or the branches are very heavy, it's definitely advisable to call in a professional arborist to ensure safety and proper care for your tree. 

Good luck! If you have any further questions, feel free to ask!

Human: I will trim the hanging branches.  How often should I check on the tree for signs of distress and what are signs of distress?


Assistant: Great! Regular monitoring can help you catch any issues early and address them promptly. Here’s a guide on how often to check your tree and what signs of distress to look out for:

### Frequency of Inspection
- **Regular Check-ups:** Check your tree every few weeks during the growing season (spring and summer), especially after storms or other weather events.
- **Seasonal Monitoring:** Conduct more thorough inspections in the spring and fall when the tree is transitioning between
